fr:title.text: Monad container distributive law from compatible composite

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monad container distributive law from compatible composite

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let (S \triangleleft P, \iota ^S, \sigma ^S, \text {pr}^S) and (T \triangleleft Q, \iota ^T, \sigma ^T, \text {pr}^T) be monad containers and (\sigma , \text {pr}) be a compatible composite of these monad containers (of type T \triangleleft Q \circ S \triangleleft P). We can define a monad container distributive law (of type S \triangleleft P \circ T \triangleleft Q \Rightarrow T \triangleleft Q \circ S \triangleleft P) as follows:
\begin {align*} u\ s\ f &:= \sigma \ (\iota ^T, \lambda \_ . s)\ (\lambda p . (f\ (\pi _2\ p), \lambda \_ . \iota ^S))\\ v\ q\ p &:= (\pi _2\ (\text {pr}_1\ (q , p)) , \pi _1\ (\text {pr}_2\ (q , p))) \end {align*}

Following an idea Stef and I had a couple months ago, I'm going to specialse monad container distributive laws to the case where v = \langle \pi _2 , \pi _1 \rangle , which often seems to be the case in simple examples.

Essentially by adopting v = \langle \pi _2 , \pi _1 \rangle , all of the position equalities become trivial, and we are just left with shape equalities (with no mention of v). Hopefully it will be easier to prove things in this simpler case!

If we look at the compatible composites (\sigma , \text {pr}) corresponding to distributive laws with v = \langle \pi _2 , \pi _1 \rangle , we get that:
\begin {align*} p = \pi _2\ (\text {pr}_1\ (q , p))\\ q = \pi _1\ (\text {pr}_2\ (q , p))\\ \end {align*}

These are in bijection with the compatible compositions of the monad container extensions of the relevent monad containers, and thus are also in bijection with the relevent types of monad container distributive law.
Monad container distributive laws allow you to define a notion of composition for monad containers. They are in bijection with compatible compositions of monad containers.
